column2: Mars Helicopter Ingenuity makes successful first flight on another planet
column5: Just a few minutes ago telemetry data came back from Mars reporting on the first instance of aÂ powered controlled flight on another planet.Â And it is a high-flying success!Â The Mars helicopter Ingenuity made history to executing its command sequence autonomously rising a few feet above the surface of Mars and landing back successfully all in the thin atmosphere and low gravity of Mars. "Ingenuity has performed its first flight â€” the first flight of a powered aircraft on another planet!"The data reveals: Our #MarsHelicopter has had a successful first flight: ğŸš pic.twitter.com/h5a6aGGgHG  "Wow!"The @NASAJPL team is all cheers as they receive video data from the @NASAPersevere rover of the Ingenuity #MarsHelicopter flight: pic.twitter.com/8eH4H6jGKs Here is one of the first images â€”Â one of its own shadow on the rocky and dusty surface of Mars taken by Ingenuityâ€™s navigation camera - The little rotorcraft that could.ğŸšğŸ’¨Ingenuity documented its historic ascent today. Here's the #MarsHelicopter's POV during first flight. That's its shadow on the ground below. pic.twitter.com/wXgLyTDbjm And here is a short video from Perseverance stationedÂ 64.3 metersÂ away atÂ Van Zyl Overlook. Witness the historic moment in full. The Mastcam-Z cameras on @NASAPersevere show us the takeoff hovering and landing of the #MarsHelicopter. pic.twitter.com/ypdIWmC4D1 This short test flight is being compared withÂ the first flight by Wilbur and OrvilleÂ Wright. The area where the flight took place has been wrightfully named the Wright Brothers Field. As an homage to the two innovative bicycle makers from Dayton this first of many airfields on other worlds will now be known as Wright Brothers Field in recognition of the ingenuity and innovation that continue to propel exploration. #MarsHelicopter pic.twitter.com/ytZ7eOdc2k Some more info From www.nasa.gov/â€¦ - The solar-powered helicopter first became airborne at 3:34 a.m. EDT (12:34 a.m. PDT) â€“ 12:33 Local Mean Solar Time (Mars time) â€“ a time the Ingenuity team determined would have optimal energy and flight conditions. Altimeter data indicate Ingenuity climbed to its prescribed maximum altitude of 10 feet (3 meters) and maintained a stable hover for 30 seconds. It then descended touching back down on the surface of Mars after logging a total of 39.1 seconds of flight. Confirmation of the flight arrived at JPL at 6:46 a.m. EDT. There will be a news briefing today at 2:00 p.m. EDT. A second experimental test flight is likely on Thursday April 22. Why is this flight such a big deal? Aside from operating under extreme cold conditions on a planet 50 million km away Ingenuity has to operate in an atmosphere whose surface pressure is about 0.65% that on earth. On earth pressure drops to about 4% at an altitude of 20 km (about 65616Â feet). No drone or rotorcraft on earth has every flown at 20 km altitude let alone at a pressure of 0.65% atmospheres. About the Ingenuity Helicopter NASAâ€™sÂ Mars Helicopter IngenuityÂ is the first to demonstrate powered flight on another world. It is a technology demonstration and assessment experiment and is not critical to the primary mission. It will provide a scouting service for Perseverance by surveying the area around the rover flying in the thin atmosphere and low gravity of Mars. The one-way signal travel time between Mars and EarthÂ is around 16Â minutes (on April 19) so real-time remote piloting of the helicopter is out of question. Flight plans will uploaded by controllers at JPL; however Ingenuity will use autonomous control to manage its flight. Used to communicate with theÂ PerseveranceÂ rover Radio link using low-powerÂ ZigbeeÂ communication protocol 250 kbit/s over distances of up to 1000 m. Solar tracker camera and visual inertial navigation system The inconsistent Mars magnetic field precludes the use of a compass  Perseverance NASAâ€™sÂ Mars 2020Â spacecraft and theÂ PerseveranceÂ RoverÂ arrivedÂ at Mars on Feb 18. The Perseverance rover successfully landed inÂ Jezero Crater a large impact crater about 45 km wide just north of the Martian equator. Jezero once contained a lake which scientists think is one of the most ideal places to find evidence of ancient microbial life the primary objective of this mission. Â The rover will also collect and store rock and regolith samples which will be returned to Earth in a future mission for further analysis. Check out diary â€œThe Mars 2020 Perseverance Rover and the Search for Lifeâ€ for more info about the mission. Some more info for TechnologyÂ Geeks If you remember this flight was postponedÂ from last week because of a glitch in one of the pre-flight tests. Over the last week NASA wasÂ testing two solutions to address the â€œwatchdogâ€ timer issueÂ that prevented the helicopter from transitioning to â€œflight modeâ€ -Â 1) adjusting the command sequence from Earth to slightly alter the timing of this transition and 2) modifying and reinstalling the existing flight control software which has been stable and healthy for close to two years. The first solution requiredÂ adding a few commands to the flight operations sequence. The first solution was used in todayâ€™s successful flight. The 2nd solution remains as a backup. The Future of Flight To be clear this short test flight is the smallÂ first step in flying on another world. In the coming weeks Ingenuity willÂ fly up to five times during its 30-day test campaign.Â If will fly 3â€“5 metres above ground for up to 90 second missions traveling as far as 50 metres downrange and back. Future missions will probably include flying drones which greatly expandÂ the capabilityÂ of exploring and studying Mars. And other planets and moons. NASA already has plans to send a flying drone to Saturnâ€™s moon Titan.Â Dragonfly will launch in 2026 and arrive in 2034. Hopefully one day humankind will fly around Mars routinely. Epilogue Three cheers to Perseverance andÂ Ingenuity â€”Â we need more of them in our lives. Let us be inspiredÂ to Dare Mighty Things. Perseverance got us to Mars. With Ingenuity we soar higher.The #MarsHelicopter made history today by being the first craft to achieve controlled powered flight on a planet beyond Earth. Further Reading
